summary.text:
A query builder for the models.

A query is lazy, meaning that it will not execute until you call one of the methods.

A query is linked to a model, meaning that you can only query the model that you created the query from.

content.text: Model
filter
and
orderBy
for how queries are usually created

summary.text: The model to query
The model to query

text.comment: The model to query

A query builder for the models.

A query is lazy, meaning that it will not execute until you call one of the methods.

A query is linked to a model, meaning that you can only query the model that you created the query from.

See:

Model: filter and orderBy for how queries are usually created

summary.text:
Utility function to handle a cursor's cycle.
This implement the limit, offset and filter.

content.text: - A promise that resolves when the cursor is done

summary.text: The callback to call for each value

text.comment: The callback to call for each value

summary.text: The transaction or mode to use

text.comment: The transaction or mode to use

Utility function to handle a cursor's cycle. This implement the limit, offset and filter.

Returns:
  • A promise that resolves when the cursor is done

summary.text: Look for a simple filter in the query's filters.

content.text: - The first simple filter found, or null if none was found

text.comment:
Look for a simple filter in the query's filters.

Returns:
  • The first simple filter found, or null if none was found

summary.text: Checks if the given instance fits the filters of the query.

content.text: - Whether the instance fits the filters

summary.text: The instance to check

text.comment: The instance to check

Checks if the given instance fits the filters of the query.

Returns:
  • Whether the instance fits the filters

summary.text:
Utility function to get the cursor of the query.
If the query has an order, it will use the index of the order.
Otherwise, if the query has a simple filter, it will use the index of the filter + add a query.

text.comment:
Utility function to get the cursor of the query. If the query has an order, it will use the index of the order. Otherwise, if the query has a simple filter, it will use the index of the filter + add a query.

Returns:

summary.text:
Get the appropriate key range for the given simple filter.
If the filter is a BetweenFilter, it will return the key range of the filter.
Otherwise, it will return a key range with just the value.

content.text: - The key range for the simple filter

summary.text: The value of the simple filter

text.comment: The value of the simple filter

Get the appropriate key range for the given simple filter. If the filter is a BetweenFilter, it will return the key range of the filter. Otherwise, it will return a key range with just the value.

Returns:
  • The key range for the simple filter

summary.text: Executes the query and returns all the results.

content.text: - All the results of the query

text.comment:
Executes the query and returns all the results.

Returns:
  • All the results of the query
Example:
// Get all users with the name "John"
const users = await User.filter({ name: 'John' }).all()

summary.text:
Creates a copy of the current query.
This allows a query to branch off into multiple queries.

content.text: - The cloned query

text.comment:
Creates a copy of the current query. This allows a query to branch off into multiple queries.

Returns:
  • The cloned query
Example:
// Regular pagination
const userPage = User.orderBy('id').offset(10).limit(10)

// Filtered pagination
const johnPage = userPage.clone().filter({ name: 'John' })
const janePage = userPage.clone().filter({ name: 'Jane' })

summary.text: Executes the query and returns the number of results.

content.text: - The amount of results of the query

text.comment:
Executes the query and returns the number of results.

Returns:
  • The amount of results of the query
Example:
// Get the amount of users with the name "John"
const amount = await User.filter({ name: 'John' }).count()

summary.text: Executes the query and deletes all the results.

content.text: - The amount of results deleted

text.comment:
Executes the query and deletes all the results.

Returns:
  • The amount of results deleted
Example:
// Delete all users with the name "John"
const amount = await User.filter({ name: 'John' }).delete()

summary.text:
Update the filters of the query.
This will not reset the filters, but will merge the new filters with the old ones.

For ranges, it is recommended to use a
BetweenFilter
for performance reasons.

content.text: - The query itself, to allow chaining

summary.text: The new filters to apply to the query

text.comment: The new filters to apply to the query

Update the filters of the query. This will not reset the filters, but will merge the new filters with the old ones.

For ranges, it is recommended to use a BetweenFilter for performance reasons.

Returns:
  • The query itself, to allow chaining
Example:
// Get all users with the name "John" and the age 20
const query = User.filter({ name: 'John' }).filter({ age: 20 })

summary.text: Executes the query and returns the first result.

content.text: - The first result of the query, or null if no result was found

text.comment:
Executes the query and returns the first result.

Returns:
  • The first result of the query, or null if no result was found
Example:
// Get the first user with the name "John"
const query = User.filter({ name: 'John' }).first()

summary.text:
Loops over the results of the query.
This is useful if you want to do something with each result, but don't want to wait for all the results to be fetched.
This is also useful if you want to modify the database while iterating over the results.
Any operation should use the same transaction as the one passed to the callback.

If the callback returns true, the loop will stop.

content.text: : For some limitations of this system

summary.text: The callback to call for each result

text.comment: The callback to call for each result

summary.text: The transaction or mode to use, make sure to use 'readwrite' if you want to modify the database

text.comment: The transaction or mode to use, make sure to use 'readwrite' if you want to modify the database

Loops over the results of the query. This is useful if you want to do something with each result, but don't want to wait for all the results to be fetched. This is also useful if you want to modify the database while iterating over the results. Any operation should use the same transaction as the one passed to the callback.

If the callback returns true, the loop will stop.

See:

: For some limitations of this system

Example:
// Log all users with the name "John"
await User.filter({ name: 'John' }).forEach((user) => {
  console.log(user)
})
// Log all users with the name "John" and delete them
await User.filter({ name: 'John' }).forEach(async (user, tx) => {
  console.log(user)
 await user.delete(tx)
})

summary.text:
Add a limit to the query.
This means that the query will only return a maximum of
`limit`
items.

content.text: - The query itself, to allow chaining

summary.text: The maximum amount of items to return

text.comment: The maximum amount of items to return

Add a limit to the query. This means that the query will only return a maximum of limit items.

Returns:
  • The query itself, to allow chaining
Example:
// Get the first 10 users
const query = User.limit(10)

summary.text:
Add an offset to the query.
This means that the query will skip the first
`offset`
items.

content.text: - The query itself, to allow chaining

summary.text: The amount of items to skip

text.comment: The amount of items to skip

Add an offset to the query. This means that the query will skip the first offset items.

Returns:
  • The query itself, to allow chaining
Example:
// Get all users except the second page of 10 users
const query = User.limit(10).offset(10)

summary.text:
Update the field used to order the query.

Given that this uses the index under the hood, you have to choose between using this or
withIndex

;
up to you to benchmark which one is faster.

content.text: - The query itself, to allow chaining

summary.text: The field to order the query by, prepend with
to reverse the order

text.comment: The field to order the query by, prepend with - to reverse the order

Update the field used to order the query.

Given that this uses the index under the hood, you have to choose between using this or withIndex; up to you to benchmark which one is faster.

Returns:
  • The query itself, to allow chaining
Example:
// Get all users ordered by their name ascending
const query = User.orderBy('name')
// Get all users ordered by their name descending
const query = User.orderBy('-name')

summary.text: Reset the filters of the query.

content.text: - The query itself, to allow chaining

text.comment:
Reset the filters of the query.

Returns:
  • The query itself, to allow chaining
Example:
// Get all users with the name "John"
const query = User.filter({ name: 'John' })
// Get all users
query.resetFilters()

summary.text: Change the order of the query.

content.text: - The query itself, to allow chaining

text.comment:
Change the order of the query.

Returns:
  • The query itself, to allow chaining
Example:
// Get all users ordered by their name ascending
const query = User.orderBy('name')
// Get all users ordered by their name descending
query.reverse()

summary.text: Executes the query and updates all the results.

content.text: - The amount of results updated

summary.text: The updates to apply to the results

text.comment: The updates to apply to the results

Executes the query and updates all the results.

Returns:
  • The amount of results updated
Example:
// Update all users with the name "John" to have the name "Jane"
const amount = await User.filter({ name: 'John' }).update({ name: 'Jane' })

summary.text:
Define the index to use for the query, with an optional filter query.
Given that the orderBy also uses the index, only one can be used at once,
up to you to benchmark which one is faster.
The index to use

text.comment: The index to use

summary.text: The query to use on the index

text.comment: The query to use on the index

Define the index to use for the query, with an optional filter query. Given that the orderBy also uses the index, only one can be used at once, up to you to benchmark which one is faster.

Returns:
